content: Irwin, the taser is the tool of contemporary LE. Despite certain rare cases of misuse, LE administrators are expanding its use. Our new hires are getting them issued to them and take them home. They have been determined safer than any other police weapon. The baton can crack bones and leave protracted injuries. The taser is effective and temporary. Our courts have classified them as non-leathel, which is virtually minimum-use-of-force. I'm not familiar with any successful lawsuits against using one as of yet. The taser has reduced prisoner injuries and officer injuries. Our County Attorney says litigation costs have been reduced compared to using asps, batons, or other weapons. None will be perfectly safe in a violent prone situation, but the taser is here to stay. I'm just passing on what my agency is saying & I'm not certain on all these aspects. I've only deployed the taser once & it didn't work for me. We had to take care of business the old fashion way; thump/ thud.

content: I see second guessing the man on the scene is still the order of the day. I am not, nor ever was a policeman, I was however a certified security officer and a nuclear security officer. I have been trained to use a taser, and I have been tagged with them on two separate occassions, once per cert. My training was that the taser was the prefered non-leathal force medium. It went like this for the levels of force, voice commands, non-leathal force(in form of mace and taser depending on situation), deadly force. I was trained that grappling with someone was the least prefered method to use, ever, under any circumstances. Why? You do not know the intent or capabilities of a given individual. He may have a knife, gun, or other weapon. You move to man-handle a person and get stabbed, then you are done. It is on you, and a bullet resistant vest is of rather little help against a sharp object. I support the officer electing to use his taser on a suspect resisting arrest. It was the best option for minimal risk of severe harm to the officer and the suspect. Sadly, the suspect turned out to be guilty of nothing more than fear, and suffered death via means of a normally non-lethal device. That is regretable, however, I cannot say that I would have acted any differantly than the officer on the scene in the same situation. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

content: I see second guessing the man on the scene is still the order of the day. I am not, nor ever was a policeman, I was however a certified security officer and a nuclear security officer. I have been trained to use a taser, and I have been tagged with them on two separate occassions, once per cert. My training was that the taser was the prefered non-leathal force medium. It went like this for the levels of force, voice commands, non-leathal force(in form of mace and taser depending on situation), deadly force. I was trained that grappling with someone was the least prefered method to use, ever, under any circumstances. Why? You do not know the intent or capabilities of a given individual. He may have a knife, gun, or other weapon. You move to man-handle a person and get stabbed, then you are done. It is on you, and a bullet resistant vest is of rather little help against a sharp object. I support the officer electing to use his taser on a suspect resisting arrest. It was the best option for minimal risk of severe harm to the officer and the suspect. Sadly, the suspect turned out to be guilty of nothing more than fear, and suffered death via means of a normally non-lethal device. That is regretable, however, I cannot say that I would have acted any differantly than the officer on the scene in the same situation. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.
